category.title: Digital agenda
category.description: This tracker monitors Horizon Europe‚Äôs financial contribution to the development of digital technologies and the digitisation of the economy and society (known as ‚ÄòDigital transition‚Äô).

category.title: Clean air
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe‚Äôs financial contribution to the clean air policy (National Emission Ceiling Directive) aiming to improve ambient air quality and tackle air pollution, to protect the environment and human health.

category.title: Artificial intelligence
category.description: This tracker monitors Horizon Europe‚Äôs financial contribution to the development and deployment of AI-based technologies and solutions. Projects that develop AI-tools as part of their research method are included

category.title: Climate action
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe‚Äôs financial contribution to both mitigating climate change (e.g., contributions to the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions) and adapting to climate change by building resilience (e.g., regarding floods, droughts, spatial planning and better governance, adaptation to changing climate in value chains, etc.).

category.title: Biodiversity
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe‚Äôs financial contribution to Europe‚Äôs biodiversity‚Äôs path to recovery including species protection, ecosystem conservation, and habitat rehabilitation, all essential for resilience in climate adaptation and addressing ecosystem services but also environmental crime and the health-environment connection.

result.title: Work Package Report for JUSTscore Integration
result.description: This will be a comprehensive integrated report will be written by Professor Nymand Larsen. The report will compare and evaluate the sustainability of current economic practices across the Arctic. It will discuss how simulation exercises from JUSTscore determined what changes could be made to improve the sustainability status of these economic practices and how new development of these economic activities in the future could achieve the standards necessary to achieve sustainability through application of JUSTscore methodology

result.title: Report on the preconditions for the sustainability of the Network and recommendations for its long term success
result.description: Based on the key factors for the long term sustainability assessment identified T42 the report will present the results of the coconstruction of the preconditions for the sustainability of the Network with NCPs key actors of the pilot network DG Agri and the external advisory board and derive recommendations for the long term success of the European Network that will guide the development of the implementation plan in T44

article.title: Understanding gender inequalities in parenthood
article.teaser: Entrenched gender disparities ‚Äì rather than financial concerns ‚Äì are the key drivers that determine how parents divide up work and care, according to new research.

section.sectionBody:
The transition to parenthood marks a point where gender inequalities in the labour market ‚Äì and within couples ‚Äì become more pronounced. Across the world, the birth of a child often decreases a woman‚Äôs employment prospects, while men tend to be unaffected.
‚ÄúIn different-sex couples, studies suggest that comparative advantages within the household and the labour market are inevitably linked to gender,‚Äù explains https://www.su.se/genparent-research-project/ (GENPARENT) project coordinator Marie Evertsson from https://www.su.se/english/ (Stockholm University) in Sweden. ‚ÄúThis can make it difficult to separate financially rational decision-making from gender norms and expectations.‚Äù

The GENPARENT project, which was funded by the https://erc.europa.eu/homepage (European Research Council), focused on parenthood within same-sex couples. The goal was to study how parents divide paid work and care when https://op.europa.eu/en/publication-detail/-/publication/091c2a6c-9e91-11ec-83e1-01aa75ed71a1 (gender disparities) can be ruled out as determining their division.
The research was based on analyses of large-scale population register data across the Nordic countries and the Netherlands, as well as interviews with lesbian couples expecting (and having) a baby in the Netherlands and Sweden.
‚ÄúResults showed that within lesbian couples, both women often want to carry a child at some point,‚Äù says Evertsson. ‚ÄúIn addition, both lesbian and gay male couples share parental leave more equally than different-sex couples do.‚Äù
Although the project‚Äôs analyses of male couples were based on a smaller population with higher incomes and better labour market positions than most men, they suggest that male couples share the care of the child most equally. An important reason for this seems to be the absence of physiological factors (such as breastfeeding) that tie one parent closer to the child.

The project also compared couples‚Äô earnings trajectories in the Nordic countries. ‚ÄúSame-sex couples have fairly equal earnings five years after a first birth in Denmark, Norway and Sweden,‚Äù adds Evertsson. ‚ÄúIn Finland however, we found that both different-sex and same-sex couples have a considerable earnings gap five years after their first birth.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe Finnish cash-for-care policy seems to be a significant factor here, contributing to within-couple inequalities in both groups of couples,‚Äù notes Evertsson.
The project also found a similar division of leave among adoptive and biological different-sex parents, with the mother taking the first and longest leave in both groups. This suggests that gender norms and ideals are strong mechanisms that spur inequalities in paid work and care in different-sex couples.
Finally, analyses also found that individuals who have lived with both a man and a woman work more hours when they live with a woman rather than a man. ‚ÄúThis aligns with our hypothesis that a partner‚Äôs gender influences labour market behaviour,‚Äù says Evertsson.

section.sectionTitle: Understanding the gendered transition to parenthood
section.sectionBody:
Evertsson believes that the GENPARENT project has achieved a better understanding of the mechanisms that produce inequalities in different-sex couples transitioning to parenthood.
‚ÄúWe were also able to fill a gap in research by focusing on family models that are becoming more common, yet still seldom included in large-scale, quantitative studies of earnings inequalities,‚Äù she adds.
‚ÄúOur results challenge traditional theories on couples‚Äô division of work and care being determined by financial concerns. Instead, they point to the importance of gender disparities and norms when it comes to understanding the gendered transition to parenthood.‚Äù

article.keywords: GENPARENT, gender, parent, parenthood, same-sex, breastfeeding, earnings

project.teaser: This project is the first to apply an inclusive, internationally comparative, multi-methods approach to families to reveal the complex processes that result in a gendered division of work. We do this by comparing different-sex couples (DSC) to same-sex couples (SSC) focusing...
project.title: Revealing Sources of Gendered Parenthood: A multi-method comparative study of the transition to parenthood in same-sex and different-sex couples

result.title: D3.2 Guidelines for the sustainability and resilience of IWT&L
result.description: "The guidelines will be based on the ISO 22301 Business continuity management systems, ISO 37123, Sustainable cities and communities ‚Äì Indicators for resilient cities, ISO/TS 22375:2018 Security and resilience ‚Äî Guidelines for complexity assessment process, ISO 1406x series for assessing and verifying GHG emissions, ISO 14090 Managing the impact of climate change, ISO 22320:2018 Emergency management ‚Äî Guidelines for incident management, ISO 55001 Asset management , ISO 14001 Environmental quality management, ISO 50001 Energy Management System, ISO 26000 social accountability, ""Taxonomy"" Regulation EU 852/2020, Dir.CE 95/2014 Corporate sustainability reporting on the social and environmental impacts of their activities, EC TAXONOMY."

category.title: Digital agenda
category.description: This tracker monitors Horizon Europe‚Äôs financial contribution to the development of digital technologies and the digitisation of the economy and society (known as ‚ÄòDigital transition‚Äô).

category.title: Clean air
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe‚Äôs financial contribution to the clean air policy (National Emission Ceiling Directive) aiming to improve ambient air quality and tackle air pollution, to protect the environment and human health.

category.title: Artificial intelligence
category.description: This tracker monitors Horizon Europe‚Äôs financial contribution to the development and deployment of AI-based technologies and solutions. Projects that develop AI-tools as part of their research method are included

category.title: Climate action
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe‚Äôs financial contribution to both mitigating climate change (e.g., contributions to the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions) and adapting to climate change by building resilience (e.g., regarding floods, droughts, spatial planning and better governance, adaptation to changing climate in value chains, etc.).

category.title: Biodiversity
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe‚Äôs financial contribution to Europe‚Äôs biodiversity‚Äôs path to recovery including species protection, ecosystem conservation, and habitat rehabilitation, all essential for resilience in climate adaptation and addressing ecosystem services but also environmental crime and the health-environment connection.

result.title: Annual activity plan - Year II
result.description: The Year 2 Annual Activity Plan. This plan will formalise specific operations (meetings and agendas), at WP and sub-WP level for the following 12 months. The output will be formalised via the project workspace (SharePoint), and associate project management software. The plan will identify and facilitate the necessary co-ordination to help ensure the timely delivery and success of linked project activities and meetings or workshops. This plan will also help inform the framework of the DMP (D9.2).

result.title: D700.2
result.description: D700.2 Second dissemination, commercial exploitation, and sustainability report This deliverable will report on all dissemination activities during the first period of the project (M19-M30). The deliverable will describe all dissemination activities conducted, dissemination and training events organised and attended, and community feedback collected and analysed. It will also describe IPR management. This deliverable will report on all the commercial exploitation, impact and sustainability activities in the reporting period. The report will include detailed analysis of the impact planned and achieved by experiments and the project as a whole, and will describe commercial exploitation and sustainability plans of experiments and the Digital Marketplace.

result.title: Best practice guide on legume processing and inclusion
result.description: Publication of the best practice guide on legume processing and inclusion for fish and poultry feeds This will be based upon the five major feeds which are to be recommended to European animal feed producers on the basis of feeding trials that balance keynutritionals and bioactive contents The guide will also be applicable across the various pedoclimatic regions of the EU

result.title: Data for Life Cycle Analysis proof of concept
result.description: Nutritional profile data for grain legumes will be data gathered and provided for the Life Cycle Analysis proof of concept (WP5). Profiling will include that of including macro- and micro-nutrients and prebiotic properties (of selected legumes). This data will also help identify the relative suitability, and trade-offs, of different legume species for food- and feed-applications.

The plan will identify and facilitate the necessary co-ordination to help ensure the timely delivery and success of linked project activities and meetings or workshops. This plan will also help inform the framework of the DMP (D9.2).

result.title: Delphi for favourable governance contexts
result.description: This report, ‚ÄòDeveloping new governance solutions for legume-dependent systems‚Äô, will describe road-maps which may meet the expectations of a wide range of different actors‚Äô groups across the supply chain. The findings will be shared in a range of languages of the European Union. The report will be guided by the results of web-based Delphi surveys of legume chain actors to a range of potential policy solutions. Iteration in this process will allow resolution of favourable policies and transition pathways.

result.title: Annual activity plan - Year IV
result.description: The Year 4 Annual Activity Plan. This plan will formalise specific operations (meetings and agendas), at WP and sub-WP level for the following 12 months. The output will be formalised via the project workspace (SharePoint), and associate project management software. The plan will identify and facilitate the necessary co-ordination to help ensure the timely delivery and success of linked project activities and meetings or workshops. This plan will also help inform the framework of the DMP (D9.2).

result.title: D700.1
result.description: D700.1 First dissemination, commercial exploitation, and sustainability report The deliverable will report on the project website and social media profiles. The report will describe the methodology and schedule for dissemination during the whole project period (channels to be used, target audiences, activities, etc.). This deliverable will report on all dissemination activities during the first period of the project (M1-M18). The deliverable will describe all dissemination activities conducted, dissemination and training events organised and attended, and community feedback collected and analysed. It will also describe IPR management. This deliverable will report on all the commercial exploitation, impact and sustainability activities during the first part of the project. The report will include detailed analysis of the impact planned and achieved by experiments and the project as a whole, and will describe commercial exploitation and sustainability plans of experiments and the Digital Marketplace.
